qas.question: How common was divorce for samurai?
What could samurai do instead of divorce if their wife couldn't produce a son?
Why did samurai avoid divorcing for reasons of dislike?

answers.text: it would embarrass the person who had arranged the marriage
After a divorce samurai had to return the betrothal money

context: A samurai could divorce his wife for a variety of reasons with approval from a superior, but divorce was, while not entirely nonexistent, a <a0_0>rare<a0_0/> event. A wife's failure to produce a son was cause for divorce, but <a1_0>adoption of a male heir<a1_0/> was considered an acceptable alternative to divorce. A samurai could divorce for personal reasons, even if he simply did not like his wife, but this was generally avoided as <a2_0>it would embarrass the person who had arranged the marriage<a2_0/>. A woman could also arrange a divorce, although it would generally take the form of the samurai divorcing her. <a3_0>After a divorce samurai had to return the betrothal money<a3_0/>, which often prevented divorces.
